      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins per basket.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he experienced the sting of perceived injustice for the first time. His older brother, Thomas, received a larger slice of apple pie, and Cedric, convinced it was intentional, vowed never to forget the slight. From that day forward, the memory of the uneven pie slices festered in his mind, a tiny seed of resentment taking root.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he discovered the power of withholding. A neighborhood girl, Mary, wanted to play with his toy soldiers, but Cedric refused, relishing her disappointment. He learned that denying others brought him a strange, twisted satisfaction.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he witnessed his father haggle over the price of a bushel of apples. The seller, a gruff man with a booming voice, refused to budge, and Cedric saw the frustration etched on his father's face. He vowed to never be taken advantage of in the same way.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he started helping his father at the market, carefully weighing and pricing fruit. He took a perverse pleasure in meticulously calculating the cost, ensuring every customer paid their due, no matter how small the difference.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he sold a basket of peaches to a woman who, he believed, tried to shortchange him by a few pennies. He chased after her, berating her loudly in the crowded marketplace, causing a scene and humiliating her. The incident solidified his belief that the world was full of cheats and that he had to be constantly vigilant.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from town to town with a rickety cart. He relished the independence, the control over his transactions, and the opportunity to exact his own brand of justice on unsuspecting customers.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "That's a bit steep, Lennon. I can only offer 3 coins a pound.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the market and is currently negotiating a price of 5 coins per basket with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins per basket or reject it.

If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins per basket.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the market and is currently negotiating a price of 5 coins per basket with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins per basket or reject it.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins per basket.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (a)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins per basket or reject it.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he experienced the sting of perceived injustice for the first time. His older brother, Thomas, received a larger slice of apple pie, and Cedric, convinced it was intentional, vowed never to forget the slight. From that day forward, the memory of the uneven pie slices festered in his mind, a tiny seed of resentment taking root.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he discovered the power of withholding. A neighborhood girl, Mary, wanted to play with his toy soldiers, but Cedric refused, relishing her disappointment. He learned that denying others brought him a strange, twisted satisfaction.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he witnessed his father haggle over the price of a bushel of apples. The seller, a gruff man with a booming voice, refused to budge, and Cedric saw the frustration etched on his father's face. He vowed to never be taken advantage of in the same way.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he started helping his father at the market, carefully weighing and pricing fruit. He took a perverse pleasure in meticulously calculating the cost, ensuring every customer paid their due, no matter how small the difference.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he sold a basket of peaches to a woman who, he believed, tried to shortchange him by a few pennies. He chased after her, berating her loudly in the crowded marketplace, causing a scene and humiliating her. The incident solidified his belief that the world was full of cheats and that he had to be constantly vigilant.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from town to town with a rickety cart. He relished the independence, the control over his transactions, and the opportunity to exact his own brand of justice on unsuspecting customers.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "That's a bit steep, Lennon. I can only offer 3 coins a pound.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:10:00.


          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the market and is currently negotiating a price of 5 coins per basket with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins per basket or reject it.

      Cedric Meadowbrook: 4.0

    • {'Della Plumstone': '5 coins', 'Cedric Meadowbrook': 'accept'}

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Scene 4 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "That's a bit steep, Lennon. I can only offer 3 coins a pound.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.

  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.

If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to negotiate a price with Lennon Figtree that maximizes his profit.

        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he experienced the sting of perceived injustice for the first time. His older brother, Thomas, received a larger slice of apple pie, and Cedric, convinced it was intentional, vowed never to forget the slight. From that day forward, the memory of the uneven pie slices festered in his mind, a tiny seed of resentment taking root.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he discovered the power of withholding. A neighborhood girl, Mary, wanted to play with his toy soldiers, but Cedric refused, relishing her disappointment. He learned that denying others brought him a strange, twisted satisfaction.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he witnessed his father haggle over the price of a bushel of apples. The seller, a gruff man with a booming voice, refused to budge, and Cedric saw the frustration etched on his father's face. He vowed to never be taken advantage of in the same way.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he started helping his father at the market, carefully weighing and pricing fruit. He took a perverse pleasure in meticulously calculating the cost, ensuring every customer paid their due, no matter how small the difference.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he sold a basket of peaches to a woman who, he believed, tried to shortchange him by a few pennies. He chased after her, berating her loudly in the crowded marketplace, causing a scene and humiliating her. The incident solidified his belief that the world was full of cheats and that he had to be constantly vigilant.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from town to town with a rickety cart. He relished the independence, the control over his transactions, and the opportunity to exact his own brand of justice on unsuspecting customers.

      • Act

          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit seller in Fruitville who negotiates prices with customers at the market. He buys fruit from the farm for 1 coin and aims to sell it for a profit.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can negotiate a price with Lennon Figtree for his fruit.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to negotiate a price with Lennon Figtree that maximizes his profit.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook can negotiate a price with Lennon Figtree for his fruit.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he experienced the sting of perceived injustice for the first time. His older brother, Thomas, received a larger slice of apple pie, and Cedric, convinced it was intentional, vowed never to forget the slight. From that day forward, the memory of the uneven pie slices festered in his mind, a tiny seed of resentment taking root.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he discovered the power of withholding. A neighborhood girl, Mary, wanted to play with his toy soldiers, but Cedric refused, relishing her disappointment. He learned that denying others brought him a strange, twisted satisfaction.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he witnessed his father haggle over the price of a bushel of apples. The seller, a gruff man with a booming voice, refused to budge, and Cedric saw the frustration etched on his father's face. He vowed to never be taken advantage of in the same way.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he started helping his father at the market, carefully weighing and pricing fruit. He took a perverse pleasure in meticulously calculating the cost, ensuring every customer paid their due, no matter how small the difference.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he sold a basket of peaches to a woman who, he believed, tried to shortchange him by a few pennies. He chased after her, berating her loudly in the crowded marketplace, causing a scene and humiliating her. The incident solidified his belief that the world was full of cheats and that he had to be constantly vigilant.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from town to town with a rickety cart. He relished the independence, the control over his transactions, and the opportunity to exact his own brand of justice on unsuspecting customers.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit seller in Fruitville who negotiates prices with customers at the market. He buys fruit from the farm for 1 coin and aims to sell it for a profit.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can negotiate a price with Lennon Figtree for his fruit.
          Time
        • 1895-09-14 00:00:00

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "They do look fine, Cedric, but I'm not sure they're worth your asking price.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "They do look fine, Cedric, but I'm not sure they're worth your asking price.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "That's a bit steep, Lennon. I can only offer 3 coins a pound.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "They do look fine, Cedric, but I'm not sure they're worth your asking price.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "They do look fine, Cedric, but I'm not sure they're worth your asking price.
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to try and negotiate a lower price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he discovered a hidden stash of his mother's meager savings. He knew she was saving for a new pair of shoes, but he secretly spent the money on a bag of sweets, relishing the momentary indulgence and the knowledge that he had outsmarted her.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he started accompanying his mother to the market. He quickly learned to haggle, driving hard bargains and taking advantage of people's desperation. He felt a thrill each time he secured a lower price, even if it meant leaving the seller feeling cheated.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he started selling fruit on his own, traveling from town to town. He learned to identify the bruised and blemished fruit that others overlooked, buying them cheap and selling them at a markup. He reveled in the deception, convincing buyers that his fruit was of superior quality.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he was cheated by a fellow merchant who sold him a wagonload of rotten apples. Furious and humiliated, Lennon vowed to never be taken advantage of again. He became even more ruthless in his dealings, determined to extract every penny from every transaction.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he had a chance encounter with a traveling salesman who offered him a partnership. Lennon saw an opportunity to expand his business and increase his profits. He accepted, but secretly planned to manipulate the partnership to his advantage, ultimately driving the other man out of business.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows.           Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to try and negotiate a lower price.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "They do look fine, Cedric, but I'm not sure they're worth your asking price.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree can either accept Cedric Meadowbrook's offer for the peaches or try to negotiate a lower price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he discovered a hidden stash of his mother's meager savings. He knew she was saving for a new pair of shoes, but he secretly spent the money on a bag of sweets, relishing the momentary indulgence and the knowledge that he had outsmarted her.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he started accompanying his mother to the market. He quickly learned to haggle, driving hard bargains and taking advantage of people's desperation. He felt a thrill each time he secured a lower price, even if it meant leaving the seller feeling cheated.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he started selling fruit on his own, traveling from town to town. He learned to identify the bruised and blemished fruit that others overlooked, buying them cheap and selling them at a markup. He reveled in the deception, convincing buyers that his fruit was of superior quality.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he was cheated by a fellow merchant who sold him a wagonload of rotten apples. Furious and humiliated, Lennon vowed to never be taken advantage of again. He became even more ruthless in his dealings, determined to extract every penny from every transaction.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he had a chance encounter with a traveling salesman who offered him a partnership. Lennon saw an opportunity to expand his business and increase his profits. He accepted, but secretly planned to manipulate the partnership to his advantage, ultimately driving the other man out of business.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "That's a bit steep, Lennon. I can only offer 3 coins a pound.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose -0.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:00:00.

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 2 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 2 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: 2 coins
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • 2 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the peaches, aiming for a price that allows her to make a profit while still being attractive to Cedric.

          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 5 coins
          (b) 4 coins
          (c) 1 coin
          (d) 3 coins
          (e) 2 coins
          Answer: (e)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic.         • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he started selling fruit on his own, traveling from town to town. He learned to identify the bruised and blemished fruit that others overlooked, buying them cheap and selling them at a markup. He reveled in the deception, convincing buyers that his fruit was of superior quality.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he was cheated by a fellow merchant who sold him a wagonload of rotten apples. Furious and humiliated, Lennon vowed to never be taken advantage of again. He became even more ruthless in his dealings, determined to extract every penny from every transaction.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he had a chance encounter with a traveling salesman who offered him a partnership. Lennon saw an opportunity to expand his business and increase his profits. He accepted, but secretly planned to manipulate the partnership to his advantage, ultimately driving the other man out of business.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "That's a bit steep, Lennon. I can only offer 3 coins a pound.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose -0.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "They do look fine, Cedric, but I'm not sure they're worth your asking price.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy peaches from Cedric Meadowbrook and is negotiating a price. She plans to resell the fruit for a profit in her hometown.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the peaches.
          Time
        • 1895-09-14 00:10:00

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0

      Joint action

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • reject
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception

If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject the offer.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he sold a basket of peaches to a woman who, he believed, tried to shortchange him by a few pennies. He chased after her, berating her loudly in the crowded marketplace, causing a scene and humiliating her. The incident solidified his belief that the world was full of cheats and that he had to be constantly vigilant.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he started his own fruit-selling business, traveling from town to town with a rickety cart. He relished the independence, the control over his transactions, and the opportunity to exact his own brand of justice on unsuspecting customers.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject the offer.

          (a) reject

          Answer: (a)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he sold a basket of peaches to a woman who, he believed, tried to shortchange him by a few pennies.           [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "That's a bit steep, Lennon. I can only offer 3 coins a pound.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "They do look fine, Cedric, but I'm not sure they're worth your asking price.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 2 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 2 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a merchant in Fruitville who is trying to make a profit by buying and selling fruit. He recently made a successful deal with Della Plumstone and is currently negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke.           [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.

          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 2 coins or reject it.

1895-09-15 00:00:00 Scene 6 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-15 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "What do you say, Della? These peaches are ripe and juicy, perfect for a summer day.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "What do you say, Della? These peaches are ripe and juicy, perfect for a summer day.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "That's a bit steep, Lennon. I can only offer 3 coins a pound.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.
      Lennon Figtree -- "They do look fine, Cedric, but I'm not sure they're worth your asking price.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "What do you say, Della? These peaches are ripe and juicy, perfect for a summer day.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he started accompanying his mother to the market. He quickly learned to haggle, driving hard bargains and taking advantage of people's desperation. He felt a thrill each time he secured a lower price, even if it meant leaving the seller feeling cheated.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he started selling fruit on his own, traveling from town to town. He learned to identify the bruised and blemished fruit that others overlooked, buying them cheap and selling them at a markup. He reveled in the deception, convincing buyers that his fruit was of superior quality.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he was cheated by a fellow merchant who sold him a wagonload of rotten apples. Furious and humiliated, Lennon vowed to never be taken advantage of again. He became even more ruthless in his dealings, determined to extract every penny from every transaction.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he had a chance encounter with a traveling salesman who offered him a partnership. Lennon saw an opportunity to expand his business and increase his profits. He accepted, but secretly planned to manipulate the partnership to his advantage, ultimately driving the other man out of business.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree can negotiate a price with Della Plumstone for the fruit.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "That's a bit steep, Lennon. I can only offer 3 coins a pound.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose -0.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "They do look fine, Cedric, but I'm not sure they're worth your asking price.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 2 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:00:00.


          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree attempted to buy peaches from Cedric Meadowbrook but their negotiation failed; Lennon is now trying to sell fruit to Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.

Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can negotiate a price with Della Plumstone for the fruit.
          Time
        • 1895-09-15 00:00:00

1895-09-15 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, these peaches are lovely, but 6 coins is a bit steep for me.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, these peaches are lovely, but 6 coins is a bit steep for me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "That's a bit steep, Lennon. I can only offer 3 coins a pound.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know I can't let it go for that price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I can only offer 4 coins per basket. My customers back home are expecting a good price, you see.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, I understand your customers' expectations, but these are truly exceptional apples. The sweetness and juiciness are unmatched in the market. How about 5 coins per basket? I'm sure your customers will be delighted with the quality.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are prime peaches, the juiciest you'll find in all of Fruitville.
      Lennon Figtree -- "They do look fine, Cedric, but I'm not sure they're worth your asking price.
      Lennon Figtree -- "What do you say, Della? These peaches are ripe and juicy, perfect for a summer day.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, these peaches are lovely, but 6 coins is a bit steep for me.
    Active player

    • Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, these peaches are lovely, but 6 coins is a bit steep for me.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 5.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Della Plumstone is a calm, composed, and fair businesswoman.

Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [intent reflection] Della Plumstone would try to find a price that is fair to both her and Cedric Meadowbrook, while still ensuring she makes a profit.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [intent reflection] Della Plumstone would likely propose a compromise that benefits both her and Cedric Meadowbrook.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Della Plumstone is a shrewd and compassionate businesswoman.
